fun_fact: At nearly 6 minutes long, this opera-rock masterpiece was considered too long for radio - but became one of the greatest hits of all time!
The song was inspired by a documentary about Africa, and none of the band members had actually been to Africa when they wrote it!
Robbie Williams wrote this song about feeling like an outcast, and it became his signature song that launched his solo career!
This album was AC/DC's tribute to their late lead singer Bon Scott and became one of the best-selling albums of all time!
The music video featured groundbreaking zombie choreography and was the first music video inducted into the National Film Registry!
Leonard Cohen wrote over 80 verses for this song and spent 5 years perfecting it - it's been covered by more than 300 artists!
Cat Stevens wrote this as a dialogue between a father and son, and famously sang both parts himself in different vocal styles!
Paul McCartney wrote this to comfort John Lennon's son Julian during his parents' divorce - 'Hey Jules' became 'Hey Jude'!
Despite the title, this song isn't about the year 1969 - Bryan Adams was only 10 years old then! It's about the summer he got his first guitar.
Paul McCartney dreamed of his late mother Mary saying 'Let it be' during troubled times with the band - she inspired this spiritual anthem!
Highway to Hell was inspired by a real highway in Australia known for its dangerous curves and accidents!
The guitar solo was played simultaneously by Don Henley and Joe Walsh using two different guitars for a unique layered sound!

song: Another One Bites The Dust - Remastered 2011
fun_fact: This song's bassline was inspired by Chic's 'Good Times' and became Queen's biggest hit in the US!
Michael Jackson learned to moonwalk while singing live for performances that made this song legendary!

song: Rocket Man (I Think It's Going To Be A Long Long Time)
fun_fact: This classic was written in just 15 minutes at a hotel piano - one of the fastest-written hits in rock history!
The distinctive opening riff was created by accident when Angus Young was warming up his guitar during a recording session!
This song tells the true story of a fire at a casino in Switzerland that Deep Purple witnessed firsthand!

song: Stayin' Alive - From Saturday Night Fever Soundtrack
fun_fact: The BPM of this song perfectly matches the ideal chest compression rate for CPR - it literally helps save lives!
This anthem was designed to get stadium crowds singing along - there's no chorus, just one big sing-along!
This song features one of the highest notes ever hit in a pop song and an innovative rotoscoped music video!
This was AC/DC's first international hit and features the classic line 'Oi! Oi! Oi!' that became their signature chant!
Paul McCartney woke up with this complete melody in his head and initially called it 'Scrambled Eggs'!

song: Sweet Dreams (Are Made of This) - 2005 Remaster
fun_fact: This song was created in a home studio and launched Eurythmics to international stardom with its dark, synth sound!
This song marked Bon Jovi's successful transition from 80s hair metal to a more mature rock sound in the 2000s!

song: Wake Me Up Before You Go-Go
fun_fact: George Michael wrote this after finding a note his bandmate Andrew left for his parents saying 'wake me up up'!
This song was designed specifically to get stadium crowds involved - the stomp-stomp-clap rhythm is impossible to resist!
This became the anthem of German reunification and was inspired by the fall of the Berlin Wall!
Despite being Oasis's biggest hit, Noel Gallagher has said he doesn't know what 'Wonderwall' actually means!
Elvis recorded this in just one take, and it became his signature ballad and wedding song favorite!
Neil Diamond wrote this about Caroline Kennedy when she was 11 years old, and it became Boston Red Sox's unofficial anthem!
This song has been covered over 400 times and was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame!
This was The Jackson 5's debut single and made 11-year-old Michael Jackson the youngest lead singer to top the charts!

song: Take Me Home Country Roads - Rerecorded
fun_fact: John Denver had never been to West Virginia when he wrote this song, but it became the state's official song!
This charity single brought together 46 of the biggest stars of the 80s to raise money for famine relief in Africa!
Fool's Garden's biggest hit was written about waiting and became a worldwide phenomenon despite being by a German band!
This was the first a cappella song to reach #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 - Bobby McFerrin used only his voice!
Earth, Wind & Fire chose 'September' because it sounded good rhythmically, not for any special meaning!
Lou Bega's hit was based on a 1949 mambo song and became one of the biggest one-hit wonders of the 90s!
This song was Lynyrd Skynyrd's response to Neil Young's 'Southern Man' and became an unofficial Southern anthem!
The famous keyboard riff was created on a cheap Yamaha keyboard and became Europe's signature song!
Joan Jett heard this song in a London club and decided to cover it - her version became bigger than the original!
Eddie Van Halen initially didn't want to use keyboards, but 'Jump' became Van Halen's only #1 hit!
This disco anthem was originally written for Donna Summer, but she passed on it before The Weather Girls made it famous!
This gospel-influenced Queen masterpiece features some of the most complex harmonies in rock music!
Aretha Franklin transformed Otis Redding's song into a feminist anthem and made it completely her own!
Toto wrote this song about actress Rosanna Arquette, and it won a Grammy for Record of the Year!
Freddie Mercury considered this his favorite Queen song to perform live because of its pure joy and energy!
Whitney Houston's version holds the record for the longest-running #1 single by a solo artist!
The Beach Boys based this on Chuck Berry's 'Sweet Little Sixteen' and had to give him writing credit!
Michael Jackson's famous 45-degree lean in the music video required specially designed shoes and practice!
The Pointer Sisters' high-energy hit became a staple at sporting events and dance clubs worldwide!

song: I Wanna Dance with Somebody (Who Loves Me)
fun_fact: This was Whitney Houston's attempt to create a fun, danceable song after her more serious ballads!
Billy Joel wrote this about his relationship with Elle Macpherson, but ended up marrying Christie Brinkley instead!
Madonna's tribute to dancing and music became her 12th #1 hit and marked her transition into electronic music!
The Cranberries wrote this powerful protest song about The Troubles in Northern Ireland!
Gloria Gaynor's disco anthem became the ultimate breakup song and feminist empowerment anthem!
This was the first video by a Black artist to receive heavy rotation on MTV, breaking down racial barriers!
This Flashdance hit was created specifically for the movie and became Michael Sembello's biggest success!
Toto's debut single showcased their technical prowess and became a classic rock radio staple!
Kool & The Gang's party anthem was written to celebrate good times and became a universal celebration song!
Green Day's breakthrough hit about anxiety disorders helped bring punk rock to mainstream radio!
This song marked the Backstreet Boys' return and became one of their most iconic hits!
Liquido's one-hit wonder became a huge success across Europe with its distinctive guitar riff!
The Verve had to give up all royalties because they sampled a Rolling Stones orchestral version!
Caesars' garage rock hit became famous through iPod commercials and video game soundtracks!
Robbie Williams' comeback single proved he could succeed as a solo artist after leaving Take That!

song: The Show Must Go On - Remastered 2011
fun_fact: Freddie Mercury recorded this while seriously ill, creating one of Queen's most powerful and emotional songs!
Chubby Checker's follow-up to 'The Twist' proved the dance craze was here to stay!
This classic collaboration between Queen and David Bowie was recorded spontaneously when Bowie visited their studio!
John Lennon sang this while sick with a cold, which gave his voice the raw, raspy sound that made it iconic!

song: The Sound of Silence - Acoustic Version
fun_fact: This song was initially a flop until producer Tom Wilson added electric instruments without telling Simon & Garfunkel!
Billy Joel crammed 119 historical events into this song after someone said his generation didn't care about history!
Elton John wrote this as a tribute to early rock and roll, and it became his first #1 hit in the US!

song: You Give Love A Bad Name
fun_fact: This Bon Jovi hit was co-written with Desmond Child and became their signature anthem about love gone wrong!
Kurt Cobain wrote this about teen apathy, not knowing 'Teen Spirit' was a deodorant brand!

song: Girls Just Want to Have Fun
fun_fact: Originally written by a man, Cyndi Lauper transformed it into a feminist anthem that defined the 80s!
Haddaway's Eurodance hit became a global phenomenon and was famously featured in 'A Night at the Roxbury'!
Guns N' Roses wrote this about the contrast between the gritty city life and dreams of escape to paradise!
Irene Cara's movie theme song became a dance floor anthem and won an Academy Award!
This Nirvana classic encouraged people to be themselves and became an alternative rock anthem!
The Backstreet Boys' biggest hit has lyrics that don't make logical sense, but the melody was too good to change!
Bon Jovi's signature song features a talk box effect and tells the story of working-class struggles!
The famous opening riff came from a guitar warm-up exercise that Slash was playing randomly!
Linkin Park's breakthrough hit perfectly captured millennial angst and became their most successful song!
